answers.answer: Your vet should check for Addisons disease (endocrine disorder), IBD (GI and possible allergic), Stress Colitis (emotional GI problem), Pancreatic Insufficiency (GI problem due to lack of digestive enzymes), food allergies (dogs can be allergic to anything in regular dog food), or GI parasites.  These include the most common possibilities.All of these diseases can cause the symptoms you describe and may be the reason the first owner gave him up to a shelter.  All of the above diseases have treatments that may involve medications, special diets or injectable medications, but they are treatable!Diagnostics for the above may include: fecal analysis for standard parasites and giardia,  blood tests for Addisons and pancreatic insufficiency, fecal culture and sensitivity,  Food Trial, and more.There may be less common causes for the problems:  A CBC, Chemistry, T4, urinalysis and abdominal X-Ray should also be perfomed as a routine data base.

question: We adopted Doc Holliday on January 14.  He is a Dalmation about 2-12 years old, and weighs 63 pounds.  He looks like he's at an ideal weight for him as he is on the larger end of Dal size.  All we know about his past is that he ended up in the county shelter for about 10 days, and was taken in by a Dal rescue organization from whom we adopted him.  The rescue group had him for one week.Every 4 to 5 days, Doc gets sick.  He vomits (usually in the middle of the night) and this follows with a day of diarrhea.  And the gas is horrific!!  :-)   I know his diet has been changed over and over again in the past several weeks, so I put these symptoms down to food changes.  A week ago I changed both dogs to Royal Canin Special 25 for dogs with sensitive tummies.  Both dogs eat love it, but Doc has vomited the last 2 nights and now has diarrhea again.  He drinks a whole lot of water, and eats 3 times as much as our other dog of the same size, but never gains weight.  Our vet checked his blood sugar levels and it was perfectly normal, so diabetes doesn't seem to be a problem.  Any ideas of what else we should investigate?  Is it possible he's still just having problems adjusting to the new diet and nothing more to worry about?
title: Dalmation Tummy Troubles
